alert.note: Alert for Carroll; Coos; Grafton (New Hampshire) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 26 at 5:20AM EDT until June 26 at 7:45AM EDT by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: The National Weather Service in Gray has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... Northeastern Carroll County in northern New Hampshire... Southeastern Coos County in northern New Hampshire... East Central Grafton County in northern New Hampshire... * Until 745 AM EDT. * At 520 AM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 1.5 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms. SOURCE...Radar and automated gauges. IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Bethlehem, Lincoln, Pinkham Notch, Mount Washington, Carroll, Gorham, Bartlett, Jefferson, Jackson and Chatham. This includes the following Rec locations... Crawford Notch State Park, Mount Jefferson, Mount Madison, Mount Eisenhower, Wildcat Mountain, Carter Notch, Kearsarge North , Moose Brook State Park, Mount Adams, Mount Isolation, AMC Highland Center, Mount Webster, Mount Moriah, AMC Mizpah Spring Hut, AMC Lake of the Clouds Hut, AMC Madison Spring Hut, AMC Carter Notch Hut, Mount Willey, Mount Field, Mount Jackson, Arethusa Falls, Ripley Falls, North Baldface, South Baldface, Mount Doublehead and Mountain Pond. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR AND GAUGE INDICATED
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Flooding is occurring or is imminent. It is important to know where you are relative to streams, rivers, or creeks which can become killers in heavy rains. Campers and hikers should avoid streams or creeks.
